content:
What's the easiest way (is there a recommended/built-in?) to show that a List with an element has positive length. Below is what I came up with

theorem list_mem_pos_length {α : Type} {x : α} (lst : List α) (h : x ∈ lst) : length lst > 0 := by
simp; rw [List.length_pos_iff_ne_nil]
intro h₁; rw [h₁] at h; apply List.not_exists_mem_nil; use x

but I would prefer to use a tactic or something for this (I personally feel that it is simple enough to be one-step; but I'm a newbie at Lean so idk what the conventions are wrt tactics)
you can use docs#List.length_pos_of_mem directly, no need to define another theorem
thanks! by the way if I'm allowed a followup--what's the fastest way to prove if i have like 5 elements pairwise distinct then the length is at least 5?
@Julian Berman the suspense is killing me :big_smile:
Ha sorry, then I realized hint wasn't giving something helpful, which still confuses me sometimes
@Andy Jiang For the first one I was going to mention that exact? is always worth trying, which indeed suggests exactly as Matt said to simply use List.length_pos_iff_ne_nil h
For the follow-up question I expected to find something that'd help in the list lemmas but I didn't see anything
(Obviously the library won't have anything about 5 but I'd expect either a lemma about sublists lst or else one with general n). So probably you get to prove it by induction I guess

Julian Berman said:

(Obviously the library won't have anything about 5 but I'd expect either a lemma about sublists lst or else one with general n). So probably you get to prove it by induction I guess

thanks! I didn't know about this exact? function it will be helpful for me in the future!

I suggest saying that [a, b, c, d, e] is a sublist (there's some notation for this) of your list. Use that length of sublist le length of list. And the proof that it is a sublist is via some extensionality lemma.
Andy Jiang has marked this topic as resolved.
